content.description:
Climb the start of the 10 on the corner, utilising the first two bolts then follow the natural line straight up and through a small roof and a stance that leads back to the right side of the arête. Follow the arête closely on positive holds to the anchor. Uses existing anchors. -Hoogstraten

On the arete, right of the steep overhanging wall. 
6 Bolts, finger sized pro (BD 0.3, 0.4)

Fun climb. Sort of zig-zags. At one point you have no feet but a great ledge, so I just sort of pull-up to the next ledge. 
 Great for beginner sport-leaders.

Center of the central wall.
Bolts and top anchors

Slabby climbing on good rock. Start left of the boulder and work you way up past 2 small roofs. Shares anchors with Northern Platitudes.

On the right hand side of the acropolis. Located on the clean slabs left of the prominent arete.
6ish bolts

I officially love this climb. Overhung with great protection. Cruxes comes near the top where you have to manage several committing laybacks. The great thing about this climb is there is a no-hands rest half way up before the cruxes, and after each crux there is good protection to place. Begins with some laybacking to a nice horizontal edge. From here head right to a really awesome jug. Place small gear here. Head up on slopey holds that are better when laybacked. First crux is making it to the next massive jug. Bad crimp and some fancy footwork will get you there. Mantel up to the no-hands rest. Catch your breath. Next is the three cruxes. Head up and left a bit. I match to get through this section. Now you have to reach up and slot your hand in the left crack. This is a semi-jam and semi-layback. Right foot out left and reach WAAAY up. Slopey hold, but again, a layback will make this feel more secure. You can get a 0.75 BD cam in here. Next is again a small crimp you can layback with a right foot out left. Again, reach WAAAY up to a shark fin, and another slopy hold above. Fist jam and then place another 0.75. Breath. Final crux! Pinch the giant block and reach WAAAY UP (see a theme?). Another slopy hold, then out left by the anchors a good hold. You did it!! My girlfriend can jam in this section. She's a magician. Between Taiya and Swamptart Standard rack to 1" (0.75 C4 BD cam). Anchors at the top.
Bring doubles of the 0.75 cam for near the top. They come in really handy.
Also bring small cams (0.1 and 0.2 C4 BD cam).

Variation of Sting in the Tail. Starts on arete to the right of that route. This route is now completed since 2015 and is not anymore a variation of sting in the tail. The upper section is pretty good on the arete instead of right. Right of Sting in the Tail.
Rap anchors at top. Bolts

climbs.name: Hot for Teacher
climbs.fa: Charles Kalinsky and Greg Barrett, July 2016

content.description:
Start off on the dirt slope just below an obvious ledge, more or less directly below the anchor. For fun, heel hook right off the ground to gain the ledge. Proceed straight up a series of ledges and small cracks, either trending right toward the top for an extra challenge or left toward 'Schooled' for an easier finish.

It is the farthest right route on the crag, next to 'Schooled'.
There are four bolts on the route, and a bolted top anchor with rappel rings.

First bold is high, while the move to the second bolt is tricky. 
 From there the climbing is consistent at 5.9.

To the right of Plus Tard. Right-most climb on the central wall.
Bolts and top anchor.

Starts thin and ends thin.

The right-tending line of bolts around the right hand arete.
Bolts and rap rings

Start low and left at a finger lock, working your way up and right on slopers and small edges to a small ledge at the base of a broken seam. Don't stem to the boulders out right. Climb the seam until you are forced either left or right of the bolt line, both ways are about the same difficulty and quite devious. Turn the arete to join Euthyphro at it's final bolt.

the clean face left of the obvious offwidth.
6 bolt, stick clip the first (or climb 11- above jagged boulders)

I can't remember this climb. It's fun and delicate...

Starts in the open book to the right of Easy Peasy, or I think you may be able to start this thing direct. Up to you.
Bolts and top anchor.

Start at the lowest part of the crack systems. Work your way diagonally up along the cracks, using the rock ramp to your right as you progress toward the roof. The climbing here is not too difficult, save your energy for the roof.  
  
 Pulling the roof is the crux of the climb. There are reasonably solid jams to be had in the crack at the base of the roof, but it quickly flares as your clear the roof. You'll find a small side pull on the face high to the left, and one move past it a much larger side pull.  
  
 Once you've cleared the crux, squeeze yourself into the off width crack and grind your way to the top.

This route is on the farthest right wall, the one closest to you as your approach from the trail. There is a dirt ramp below it which leads up to the top of the cliff. it can be identified by the braided crack system below, leading to a 3 foot roof, followed by a flaring offwidth on the second half.
There are 9 bolts and a bolted top anchor visible on the face of the climb.

Two cruxes: one at the bottom (bouldery) and one at the top (delicate). Once you're past the bottom crux, it's fun and awesome climbing to the last crux at the top. All of a sudden you will stop and say "hey, where did all the holds go?" Very delicate tricky move to the top. Have fun!

Right around the corner from Swamptart (to the right)
Bolts and top anchors

Amazing climb that is truly pumpy. It has some good rests, so find them and milk them. There is a crux about half-way up where you need to head left a bit and make a semi-dyno move to the lip. After this there is a great rest, and then you head up and right to slap the arete to a some good holds. From here, you need to head left into the crack and up to the anchors. This is another crux.

Right-most climb on the same side as KIA and Ginger
Bolts (I don't know how many) with fixed anchors.

Named after the deceased dog of the first ascensionist.

Stem up and into the shallow corner. Traverse left under the bulge then continue upward through easier terrain.


Left most climb on the rock. Rap rings at the top for descent.
Bolted and top anchors. Unsure of how many bolts.

Trad climb that goes up the ramp to the left of Kia then up a short crack.

To the left of Kia/Taiya
Unknown

So much fun. If you want to do this direct, then the crux would be the very beginning, and would probably promote this to a 5.10. But the fall would be nasty with no pro, so until someone bolts it, I don't recommend. Head up left in the open book (same start as Untitled Offwidth). Then move right at the thin rail. Once at the crack, start jamming and placing gear. The crack gets wider and wider. You can place up to a BD C4 #4 and #5. From there, move past the blocky roof thing. All of a sudden you're done. Weird!

To the right of the giant offwidth.
Standard rack up to 5"

I really wish this thing was less dirty. May be an easier grade if it wasn't so full of dusty-dirt. Head up the obvious fucking off-width. The thing is massive. Could probably be done with trad gear, if you have a BD C4 #6. Or a bunch of them. But seriously, you need to clean it out before committing to some jams. Without jamming, the crux is getting past the roof. So intense and delicate!!

Look for the gigantic off-width
Anchors at top. Possibly a trad route if you have really large cams.

The Acropolis / Vinyl Village is, like Grey Mountain, the Rock Gardens, or McIntyre, a good local climbing area located close to downtown Whitehorse. It is located in a valley floor, and is thus relatively shaded. Like most places in the Yukon it doesn't see much traffic. The rock is granite.
